FacilityName: Eberhart Farm Center, Inc. - Preston Plant
SafetyInspectionBy: Iowa Department of Ag & Land Stewardship

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Applicable building, electrical, and plumbing codes. This facility complies with the Iowa Fertilizer Law.
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: We utilize those portions of these codes which are deemed applicable by the jurisdictional authority
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: breakaway couplers for pullaway protection, remote emergency shut off valve
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Routine plant inspection/Routine preventive maintenance & repair
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Storage tank, pump, valves, relief valves, breakaway couplings, hoses, piping, electrical equipment and safety equipment
_prev_prog_2.Description: The prevention program is designed to identify and minimize those hazards to human health and the environment associated with the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia. Employees working at the plant follow written operating procedures and make continual observations prior to and during the transfer of anhydrous ammonia from storage vessels to nurse tanks. In so doing, they are able to detect problems before they arise. These observations also help identify equipment integrity issues so that repairs can be made before failure occurs. Employees are trained annually on the hazards associated with the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia. Many employees have been on the job for a number of years. New hires are trained prior to operating the anhydrous ammonia plant. New hire training includes classroom instruction, on-site training at the plant and observation to determine the comprehension and understanding of the new hire. Finally, the company routinely invites local fire department personnel to visit the site and assists in training fire department personnel on anhydrous ammonia if requested to do so.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility ID:  1000 0009 0215

Facility Name:  Eberhart Farm Center, LLC

Location:  2386 418th Ave, Preston, IA 52069

Contact:  John Eberhart, Manager

Work: (563) 689-3622

Cell: (563) 212-5646

 

RMP Executive Summary below:

 

1.  The Facility Policy:  The owners, management and employees of the facility are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia by utilization of proper equipment, regular inspections and maintenance, and training of all persons that work with the material.  Should an accidental release occur, the facility has coordinated with the local fire department and the local emergency planning committee to respond to any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



2.  Facility Information:  The primary activity at the facility is the storage of anhydrous ammonia for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient.  Ammonia is stored in two (2) pressurized, steel storage tanks and multiple smaller nurse tanks.



3.  The worst case release scenario is not listed in the executive summary for security reasons.  The alternate case release scenario is not listed in the executive summary for security reasons.



4.  The Accidental Release Program:   The facility complies with Iowa Administrative Code Part 21, Chapter 43, Rule 43.6(200) relating to the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia.  These regulations administered by the Department of Agriculture are consistent with ANSI K61.1 and OSHA 29 CFR 1910.111 regarding the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia.



5.  The Five Year Accident History:  There has been no accidental release of anhydrous ammonia for the covered process in the past five years that has resulted in any onsite deaths, injuries or property damage or offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage or environmental damage.



6.  The Emergency Response P

rogram:  The facility has a written emergency action plan in accordance with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.38 and provides state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III of EPCRA.  Information relevant to emergency planning, including off-site consequence analysis, is made available to the local fire department and local emergency planning committee for preparation of a community response plan.



7.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety:  Safety improvements are an on-going process at this facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe practices and operations.  There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
